div1.p: Reed makes a statement on irony in the letters he and Emilie Lawrence send each other.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, November 29, 1875
div1.p:
Your
letter to hand, at last- and I per-
ceive that you have decided
to change the day of writing.
I trust that this is only tem-
porary, however, and that when you
return to Murfreesboro, you
will again adopt Friday as
the day for correspondence- (that
is, the portion of your time that
will be devoted to me) for, I
suppose the Baltimore gentleman
must have, at least, one day out
of seven. I want Friday, anyway,
as my day, for then your let-
ters will reach me on Monday, & it is so pleasant
& cheering to get a letter from one's darling little
Sweetheart early in the week- It makes my heart
glad & inspires me with new zeal for the pers-
ecution of the week's labor-

So you have had a talk with Miss Annie on
the subject of Irony? I am really sorry that
I was not present to take part in it, since
I not only would have heard what would
be of advantage to me, but it would, also
have afforded me a chance of looking upon
your darling face- Surely, Miss Annie could
not reproduce the contents of my letter, after
so long a time has elapsed? I am sure that
I have forgotten the greater part of it; but
if you will read the letter that I did send,
I am certain you will there find my views
on the subject fully expressed, and I feel con-
fident that they are in accordance with
your sister's ideas- Yes, my darling E; it was
upon the reception of your first letter, couched
in that style of writing, that I, in reply, begged
that you would abandon it, as I feared that
it would lead to consequences which both of us
would regret- Did you so decide? Remember
that I am not trying to offer an excuse for myself-
I acknowledge that, time after time, I have been
guilty, and have often been sorry that I ad-
opted the style; and yet in my next letter I re-
peated it- To your question; “would you have our
hearts estranged”? I answer, I would not: no, not
for all that this world could bestow! Nothing could
possibly happen which would occasion me such
grief, as the knowledge that you had ceased to
love me! This is the only thing in my poor, barren
career that I can behold with pride & pleasure!
I ask no prouder distinction than to be reckoned
worthy of your love! But right here, my darling,
is where the whole secret of the style, iron-
ical, is hidden- You would keep
from me the fact that you love
me- You hold to the idea that the
heart of man must be bruised
in order to extract its fragrance,
and you would by various lit-
tle sentences, seemingly indiffe-
rent to my sensibilities, seek to
bruise and extract- And though you
are not willing that I should
think otherwise than that you
hold me in friendly esteem, yet
you would you not have me, my darling,
prostrate myself at your feet?
I have often wondered that
a lady, after accepting & promising
(I am not referring to you)
to marry a gentleman, should
take so many occasions to show
him that she cared but littlenothing for him-
and everything for some other gentleman-
a course which is certain to
engender feelings of jealousy
within
his breast,
provided he love
the lady. You may be
surprised at my state-
ment; but I candidly believe
my darling Emilie, that the man
or woman does not exist who would
not be rendered jealous by such a course-
I pray that, in the sentence previous (on the other page) to this one,
that you will not take it as referring to yourself-
I am merely speaking of the result of my observation.
And whenever you behold a lady, who is engaged, putting
pretending that she cares nothing for her lover, does it seem to
you like the sober sense of those who had arrived at maturity
and had found a just idea of the responsibilities which she had
assumed? or does it not rather appear as the silly fancies of
premature womanhood? If such things are to be regretted in
the conduct of a lady, how much more should they be discon
tenanced when practiced by a gentleman? Ah! my darling E,
neither you nor I are willing to abandon “Irony”- Oh! no! we have
the most implicit confidence in each other and in our ability to
check it on the slightest appearance of any estrange-
ment! we are thorough adepts at wielding an Ironi-
cal pen, & can gauge it so nicely that its arrows
will only pierce surface-deep-just
fan deep enough to sting a little!
what though a darling Sister
who has passed along the
same road, should
caution us,
by the love
she bears
us;
why should we listen to that?
Are we not wiser than all who
have gone before? and will we
not show our friends, that we
can yet love just as well, although
we daily insist upon it that we
have not the remotest interest
in each other! Oh! Emilie, Emilie
darling, into what treacherous
waters are our barks drifting!
Shall we discard that which will
daily imperils our safety, or shall
we retain it, only to regret our
shortsightedness when our hopes
& happiness are wrecked!
Oh! listen to the golden advice
of your darling Sister, and may
God, in his mercy, keep you free
from all sorrow-!

closer.salute:
Believe me, ever, darling,
your fond & devoted,
closer.seg:
P.S. Im telling you of the ban-
quet that I was enjoying,
I had not the slightest idea
of making you “envious”, & as
there were no ladies present
on either occasion, I am at
a loss to know how a simple
evening's enjoyment with gentlemen
could possibly make you
“Envious”--
